review.title: Recovering Communities in the General Stochastic Block Model Without Knowing the Parameters
review.abstract: Most recent developments on the stochastic block model (SBM) rely on the knowledge of the model parameters, or at least on the number of communities. This paper introduces efficient algorithms that do not require such knowledge and yet achieve the optimal information-theoretic tradeoffs identified in [AS15] for linear size communities. The results are three-fold: (i) in the constant degree regime, an algorithm is developed that requires only a lower-bound on the relative sizes of the communities and detects communities with an optimal accuracy scaling for large degrees; (ii) in the regime where degrees are scaled by $\omega(1)$ (diverging degrees), this is enhanced into a fully agnostic algorithm that only takes the graph in question and simultaneously learns the model parameters (including the number of communities) and detects communities with accuracy $1-o(1)$, with an overall quasi-linear complexity; (iii) in the logarithmic degree regime, an agnostic algorithm is developed that learns the parameters and achieves the optimal CH-limit for exact recovery, in quasi-linear time. These provide the first algorithms affording efficiency, universality and information-theoretic optimality for strong and weak consistency in the general SBM with linear size communities.
histories: arXiv admin note: substantial text overlap witharXiv:1503.00609

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: This paper examines the problem of community restoration in general stochastic block model with linear size communities, for constant and slowly diverging orders of magnitude [GN02, NWS]. Unlike [AS15], this work does not require knowledge of the SBM parameters. In particular, the problem of learning model parameters will only be solved if the average degrees differ from each other. Next, we provide some motivations for the problem and wider background of the model, with the capture of communities (or clusters) in graphs being a fundamental problem in networks, computer science and machine learning, as well as a wide variety of complex networks (e.g. social and biological networks) and datasets designed as networks in which one often tries to get a first impression of the data by trying to identify groups with similar behavior. In particular, it allows to find communities to find like-minded people in social networks [GN02, NW07, HB14, to improve recommendation systems [SMLZ].

sections.heading: 1.1 Related results on the general SBM with known parameters
sections.text: Most of the previous work concerned SBMs with symmetric communities (mainly 2 or sometimes k), with the exception of [Vu14], which provide some accessibility results for the general SBM.2 − Recently, [AS15] examined the basic boundaries for the general SBM, with the results as follows (where SBM (n, p, W) is the SBM with the community before p and the connectivity matrix W. − The first result of [AS15] concerns the regime in which the connectivity matrix scales are used as Q / n for a positive symmetric matrix Q (i.e., the node mean is constant).The following idea of SNR is introduced3SNR = | 1 / 2 / 2 max. (1) 2 [GV14] also study variations of k-symmetric modeling.

sections.heading: 1.2 Estimating the parameters
sections.text: For estimating the parameter, some results are known for bisymmetric communities, and the parameters can be estimated by restoring the communities [ABH14, BH14, Ban15]. For the constant degree regime, [MNS12] shows that the parameters above the threshold can be estimated by counting cycles (which are efficiently approximated by counting non-traceable paths), but this is true for a fixed number of communities, namely 2. Recently, we also noticed a parallel work [BCS15] that takes into account private graph estimates (including SBMs). In particular, for the logarithmic graph regime, [BCS15] receives a method for estimating graph parameters in a suitable version of the L2 standard, but this method is not efficient.

sections.heading: 2 Results
sections.text: Agnostic algorithms are developed for the constant and divergent degrees of nodes, which allow optimal accuracy scaling for large degrees of nodes and reach the limit of node divergence for logarithmic degrees in quasi-linear time. In particular, they solve the parameter estimation problems for SBM (n, p, ω (1) Q) without knowing the number of communities. An example with real data is given in Section 4.

sections.heading: 2.1 Definitions and terminologies
sections.text: The general stochastic block model SBM (n, W) is a random graph ensemble defined either on the vertex Q = [n], where each vertex v ² V is independently a hidden (or planted) marking σv in [k] under a probability distribution p = (p1,.., pk) on [k], and each (disordered) marking of nodes (u, v, V · V) is independent of the probability Wσu, σv, where Wσu, σv are planted by a symmetric k matrix W with entries in [0, 1]. Note that G ² SBM (n, W) is a random graph, which is drawn under this model without the hidden clusters (i.e., the labels of a psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho-psycho

Specifically, the exact restoration is efficient and universally solvable if it is theoretically solvable.

sections.heading: 4 An example with real data
sections.text: We tested a simplified version of our algorithm based on data from "The political blogosphere and the US Election 2004" (AG05), which includes a list of political blogs classified as liberal or conservative, and links between blogs. The algorithm we use has a few major modifications compared to our standard algorithm. First, instead of using no, r "(v" v ") as a basic tool for comparing vertices, it uses another metric, N" r, r "(v" v "), which is defined as a fraction of an edge that centered the ball of the radius r on v and an edge that is centered on v" r "but not the same edge. Measuring a fraction of the pairs instead of a count of the pairs was necessary to prevent N" r, "r" r "r" r "(v"), "v.

sections.heading: 5 Open problems
sections.text: It would be interesting to extend the current approach to smaller communities or a larger number of communities (considering the complexity scale with the number of communities), as well as to more general models with corrected degrees, marked margins, or overlapping communities (although linearly overlapping communities can be treated with the [AS15] approach).

sections.heading: 7.2 Exact recovery
sections.text: Remember that p is a probability vector of the dimension k, Q is a k · k symmetric matrix with positive entries, and G2 (n, p, Q) is the stochastic block model with the community before p and the connectivity matrix ln (n) Q / n. A random graph G drawn under G2 (n, p, Q) has a planted community assignment that we call "A1 [k] n" and eventually call the true community assignment. Also, remember that an exact recovery for a community assignment [k] = tts = 1As is solvable if there is an algorithm that assigns to each node in G an element of {A1,...] that contains its true community 7 with probability 1 − on (1). An exact recovery is solvable in SBM (n, p, W) if it can be solved for the division of [k] into singlets, i.e. all communities can be solved.

metadata.abstractText: Most recent developments on the stochastic block model (SBM) rely on the knowledge of the model parameters, or at least on the number of communities. This paper introduces efficient algorithms that do not require such knowledge and yet achieve the optimal information-theoretic tradeoffs identified in [AS15] for linear size communities. The results are three-fold: (i) in the constant degree regime, an algorithm is developed that requires only a lower-bound on the relative sizes of the communities and detects communities with an optimal accuracy scaling for large degrees; (ii) in the regime where degrees are scaled by ω(1) (diverging degrees), this is enhanced into a fully agnostic algorithm that only takes the graph in question and simultaneously learns the model parameters (including the number of communities) and detects communities with accuracy 1− o(1), with an overall quasi-linear complexity; (iii) in the logarithmic degree regime, an agnostic algorithm is developed that learns the parameters and achieves the optimal CH-limit for exact recovery, in quasi-linear time. These provide the first algorithms affording efficiency, universality and information-theoretic optimality for strong and weak consistency in the general SBM with linear size communities. ∗Program in Applied and Computational Mathematics, and EE department, Princeton University, Princeton, USA, eabbe@princeton.edu.
